list_page_teaser: Spoiler Alert!  If you have not seen Season 1, do not click!  What sort of personality types survive the best in a brutal world where the possibility of instanteous death lurks over everyone like a cloud?  Click to find out this and more!
description_html:
Game of Thrones has a lot of characters and plots. It makes sense to start with Season 1, and go from there.

Spoiler Alert! If you have not seen Season 1 of Game of Thrones in its entirety, leave this page immediately!
story_html:
It's best to have as much information about a character as possible before drawing their spiritual portrait. At the time of this writing, the series is not yet over.

It's tempting to investigate the personalities of many of the star characters, but they I am still gathering information!

As a result, this gallery contains characters who appeared only in Season 1. Characters who appear in subsequent seasons may appear in other galleries.

If you've seen the first season, you know what I'm talking about. If you haven't seen the first season, go away now!

I do not want to be the one who spoils one of the most shocking scenes in the history of television! So yeah, I am making kind of a big deal about this!

I plan to post more images of characters from other seasons of Game of Thrones soon.

To keep up to date, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Robert Baratheon
image_list.subtitle_html: King of Westeros
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The overabundance of Green in this portrait of The King shows he is not someone you want to mess with.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Robert Baratheon's dominant trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrates this trait with his constant and merciless verbal abuse of his squire, Lancel Lannister.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Robert Baratheon's auxiliary trait, his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait when he hedonisticly indulges in food, drink, and prostitutes.
image_list.story_html:
In Westeros, the slightest hint of disrespect towards The King — even a Mad King — is an act of treason. And any treasonous act, wether real or only perceived, inevitably leads to a punishment that is at best permanently shameful, and at worst severe, instantaneous, and permanent in the very worst sense of the word.

Even those closest to King Baratheon, people like his wife Cersei and his best friend Ned, tremble in fear at the thought of saying something that might somehow be interpreted as posing even the slightest affront to His Majesty's sensibilities.

Robert may seem warm and friendly to some observers, but to anyone blessed — or cursed, as the case may be — with being in a position of power in George R.R. Martin's universe, emotions such as sympathy and compassion are seen as weaknesses. And as The King, he must be hard-nosed, thick-skinned, and ultimately heartless.

Don't be fooled by his hearty laugh! It conceals a cold, cynical heart:

They never tell you how they all shit themselves [when they die in battle]. They don't put that part in the songs.

For The King to exhibit any sentimentality whatsoever in this universe is to show weakness and invite usurpation.

With a spiritual portrait similar to the one on this site of Film Noir's Mike Hammer, King Robert Baratheon is someone only a fool would try to mess with!

image_list.title: Ned Stark
image_list.subtitle_html: Lord of Winterfell
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The nice balance of both warm and cool colors in Ned's portrait show he's well-balanced and relatable.  Click on the image to learn more!
